moves.1. e4 c5 2. b4: I do not normally play this opening, because against better players I never can make up the loss of that pawn.  This gambit is the "Sicilian Wing Gambit" and each game of Ipsissimus's tournament began with this particular opening.
moves.3. Nf3: If white plays PxPc5, black responds BxPc5 and gains positional advantage.
moves.3... Nc6 4. b5 Nd4 5. Bc4 Nxf3+: I was amused by this exchange, as QxNf3 threatens mate (easily defended).
moves.6. Qxf3 Nf6: Although the queen comes out early, white seems to enjoy greater dominance of the battlefield.
moves.7. d3 b6 8. Bb2 d6 9. Nc3 Be7 10. Nd5 Nx: Black's eagerness to trade knights will prove costly.  White will pick up black's f pawn.
moves.11. Bxd5 Rb8 12. Qxf7+ Kd7 13. Qxg7: This is generally considered a "poisoned" pawn, but white ends up with the h pawn too.  In hindsight 13. Be6+ might have been better.  Kc7, 14. BxBc8 followed by Qxg7.  There is a long way to the end game, but no reason not to start trading down early.
moves.13... Kc7 14. O-O Bb7 15. f4: White thinks PxPf4, 16. QxRh8, QxQ, BxQ, RxB is a good deal, but black doesn't fall for that.
With a +4 material advantage white decides to let the trading begin in earnest.
moves.22. Qxe8: Black could pick up a pawn here with BxPh2+ before seizing the queen.
